;印度尼西亚无法解决雅加达的空气污染问题，这意味着首都的 1000 万人口将继续遭受污染环保活动人士表示，要在未来几年应对雾霾问题，并将日益恶化的问题归咎于无效的立法、不可靠的排放数据和政客对燃煤电厂的兴趣。

;

;上周，雅加达被宣布为世界上空气质量最差的城市。瑞士科技公司 IQAir 的质量评价 – 总统佐科·维多多 (Joko Widodo) 长达一个月的咳嗽甚至被归因于该市的污染水平。

;

;维多多已在下个月雅加达举行的东盟峰会之前召集部长们应对污染问题。与此同时，旅游部长桑迪亚加·乌诺(Sandiaga Uno)建议该市应该学习北京的清洁工作，北京在2013年花费了1000亿美元清除街道上的旧车辆，减少工厂排放，并用天然气代替煤炭发电。< /p>;

;“大雅加达地区的空气质量非常糟糕，”维多多上周在内阁会议上表示。 “过去三个月的旱季延长加剧了污染物水平。”

;

;尽管领导人发表了上述言论，活动人士仍对政府提出的计划能否显着改善该市的空气质量表示怀疑，他们指出

;

;2021 年 9 月，印度尼西亚一家法院裁定，包括维多多和雅加达前省长阿尼斯·巴斯韦丹 (Anies Baswedan) 在内的几名官员在处理该市空气污染问题时疏忽大意。

;

;法院没有实施任何处罚，只是敦促总统和其他人采取行动改善空气质量，包括加强监管、加强监督和测试车辆排放。

;

;政府向雅加达提起上诉2021 年 9 月向高等法院提起诉讼。当法院于 2022 年 10 月驳回这一裁决时，政府于当年 12 月向最高法院提起了新的上诉。呼吁仍在进行中。

;

;“政府最高层不想采取重要行动，”在 Baswedan 领导下担任雅加达气候变化特使的 Irvan Pulungan 表示。

;

;许多活动家指责印度尼西亚环境和林业部拒绝承认问题的严重性。

;

;该部使用的空气质量等级将远高于标准的空气污染等级划分为对人类安全的等级世界卫生组织使用的。

;

;“我们总是问他们是否意味着人类或其他物种的呼吸是安全的，”一位不愿透露姓名的活动家说。

;

;即使获得雅加达空气污染主要来源的准确数据也很棘手。纽约一家关注全球公共卫生的非政府组织 Vital Strategies 的一份报告指出，汽车尾气是主要问题。研究发现，2018-19 年期间，汽车尾气在旱季污染中占 32-41%，在雨季污染中占 42-57%。

;

;然而，Lauri Myllyvirta，首席分析师，芬兰清洁能源研究中心（CREA）表示，雅加达邻近省份的燃煤发电厂可能在污染该市空气方面发挥了更大的作用。 CREA 2020 年的一份报告发现，在城市 100 公里半径范围内，有 136 个高排放工业设施，其中包括 16 个发电厂。

;

;同一项研究发现，当道路通车时，污染并没有下降太多。交通量减少了，但当风从大量燃煤发电厂集中的地区吹来时，交通量增加了。

;

;巴厘岛的“河流勇士”清理了印度尼西亚海滩和水道的废物

;

;米利维尔塔表示，环境部似乎并不相信这个问题。在8月13日的简报中，它引用了卫星图像，显示风吹动了远离雅加达的爪哇岛西端万丹的一组植物产生的污染。然而，Myllyvirta 对此提出批评，称该部未能考察中爪哇省和西爪哇省雅加达上风口的工厂。

;

;据 Myllyvirta 称，印度尼西亚煤炭公司的政治利益使该部很难至少三名印度尼西亚内阁部长和其他政界人士持有这些公司的大量股份。

;

;国防部长普拉博沃·苏比安托 (Prabowo Subianto) 与私营 Nusantara 能源公司及其子公司 Nusantara Kaltim 煤炭公司有联系。旅游和创意经济部长桑迪亚加·乌诺 (Sandiaga Uno) 拥有投资公司 Saratoga Investama Sedaya 21.51% 的股份，该公司与煤矿公司 Adaro Energy 有关联。海事和投资部长 Luhut Binsar Panjaitan 拥有 TBS Energi Utama 8% 的股份。

;

;无论排放源和排放水平如何，印度尼西亚宽松的环境法规和薄弱的执法力度进一步加剧了处理问题的挑战污染。

;

;该国的低燃料和排放标准导致车辆燃烧更脏的发动机燃料，过滤污染物的能力较低。

;

;“我们可以说我们拥有它们”：El尼诺现象可能会毁掉印度尼西亚的热带冰川

;

;两轮和三轮车辆约占雅加达 2180 万辆汽车的 80%，其标准特别低。环境组织 KPBB 执行董事艾哈迈德·萨夫鲁丁 (Ahmad Safruddin) 表示，印度尼西亚的摩托车排放的某些污染物是汽车的四倍。

;

;当前的法规往往执行不力。在雅加达，车龄超过三年的车辆应该每年接受排放测试。 2020年，时任雅加达省长阿尼斯宣布了对未通过排放测试的车辆司机进行抽查和罚款的计划。

;

;然而，罚款计划于2021年12月被放弃，部分原因是雅加达警方质疑其可行性欧文表示，对每天进城的数百万司机实施措施。

;

;但数据表明，监管措施会鼓励驾车者遵守规定。 2021 年，当司机预计新规则生效时，自愿接受排放测试的车辆数量猛增约 3,700%，达到 481,047 辆。取消罚款计划后，此类测试的数量几乎减少了一半。

;

;省政府此前曾表示要在明年实施罚款，现在承诺对违规驾驶者的罚款将从8 月 26 日。违规者可能面临两个月监禁或最高 50 万卢比的罚款。轻便摩托车骑手将面临最高 25 万卢比的罚款。

;

;美国能否认真对待气候问题，同时为印度尼西亚炼油厂付出代价？

;

;对于燃煤电厂来说，情况类似。印度尼西亚的排放标准明显低于其他产煤国。根据 CREA 的一项研究，印度尼西亚燃煤电厂合法排放的氮氧化物（“三大”空气污染物之一）几乎是中国燃煤电厂的六倍。

;

;环境部还2019 年对所有发电厂提出了严格的新排放标准。但由于现有发电厂和根据政府合同建设的发电厂被豁免，这些标准很快就被淡化了。

;

;“雅加达受到如此多关注的原因是其他城市，尤其是中国城市，[在应对空气污染方面]取得了很大进步。”Myllyvirta 说。

;

;不过，有迹象表明情况可能会发生变化。环境部一个专注于解决大雅加达地区空气污染问题的工作组已任命了四名涉嫌违反空气污染法规的嫌疑人。嫌疑人包括一家经营铜冶炼厂的投资公司的董事，以及四名焚烧电子垃圾的经营者。

;

;8月18日，政府还宣布收紧排放标准，蒸汽发电站和重工业大雅加达地区的工厂必须开始使用洗涤器——用于去除对环境有害的物质的设备。不过，尚未具体说明时间表。

;

;由于雅加达的电力和交通基础设施问题，当局面临的清理雅加达空气标准的任务具有挑战性，Yayasan Indonesia Cerah 的执行董事 Adhityani Putri 表示。支持印度尼西亚的能源转型。

;

;“发展有点像一艘改变方向的大型油轮 - 一开始发生得非常缓慢，”Adhityani 说。

;朝鲜最近一次将间谍卫星送入轨道的尝试以失败告终媒体周四称，就在平壤首次发射升空后不久坠入大海的几个月后。

;

;朝鲜领导人金正恩已将发展天眼作为政权的首要任务，朝鲜国家航天发展局“在新型卫星上第二次发射了侦察卫星 Malligyong-1” 8月24日凌晨，千里马一号运载火箭在平安北道铁山郡西海卫星发射场发射。”官方媒体报道。

;

;

;它声称“相关事故的原因是不是一个大问题”，并誓言在调查问题并采取措施解决问题后，将在 10 月份进行第三次发射。

;

;韩国参谋长联席会议表示，在当地时间凌晨 3:50 左右检测到了这次发射。 “朝鲜声称这是一枚太空运载火箭”，并称该弹丸已“穿越了黄海上空的国际空域”。

;

;“我军正保持全面战备态势，并与美国密切配合”参谋长联席会议补充道。

;

;

;“从确保受影响居民以及飞机和船只安全的角度来看，朝鲜最近的这次发射是非常有问题的，”日本最高政府发言人松野裕和表示。

;< p>;平壤周二告诉日本海岸警卫队，发射将于 8 月 24 日至 31 日之间进行，促使东京调动船只及其 PAC-3 导弹防御系统，以防有任何物体降落在其领土上。

;

;这次发射是在华盛顿、首尔和东京领导人在美国戴维营会晤几天后进行的，也是在周一美韩举行大型联合军事演习之后进行的。

;

;

;韩国谴责此次发射，称朝鲜在“鲁莽的挑衅”上浪费资源。韩国青瓦台周四表示，在经济困境中，韩国正在为朝鲜采取进一步的军事行动做准备。

;

;美国周三敦促朝鲜不要采取进一步的威胁活动。

;

;美国周三敦促朝鲜不要采取进一步的威胁活动。美国国务院发言人表示，“太空运载火箭采用的技术与弹道导弹（包括洲际弹道导弹）所使用的技术相同且可以互换”，并批评朝鲜的最新投标违反了联合国安理会多项决议决议。

;

;虽然仍然失败，但飞行比之前的尝试取得了更大的进展，”国际战略研究所研究员约瑟夫·登普西说。

;

;“太空是艰难的，失败和吸取的教训往往是最终成功的不断发展的设计发展的一部分，”他补充说，“目前尚不清楚[朝鲜]所说的紧急爆破系统到底是什么意思，可能是指第三阶段的分离。”;

;这起事故引发了韩国为期 36 天的复杂打捞行动，涉及海军救援船、扫雷艇和深海潜水员组成的舰队。

;

;中国对事件的不作为随着美国加大压力，朝鲜可能会适得其反：分析人士

;中国出现了一种现象：人们通过严格遵守规则而获得学业成功这些所谓的“模范学生”是中国传统教育体系的产物，强调服从老师、服从父母的命令。 、过度的自我反省和对卓越的不懈追求。

;

;这条看似积极的道路可能会无意中为成年后的挑战奠定基础，因为要努力摆脱根深蒂固的对权威的服从。

;

; >;

;这种行为往往是由于不断渴望完成任务以赢得上级的赞扬和认可。

;

;另一个特征是过度自我反省。

;

;当面临压力时

;

;有些人甚至会“丢脸”，避免请假，甚至造成负面影响。他们的健康状况。

;

;这些人经常在社交媒体上受到嘲笑，他们被称为“被选中的人”。

;

;具有讽刺意味的是，虽然乍一看他们可能看起来是理想的求职者，

;

;今年一月，一群“心碎”、困惑的人在豆瓣上成立了一个名为“好学生心态受害者”的社区。网络服务和中国最著名的图书和电影评级网站。

;

;该社区发展迅速，在短短七个月内就在豆瓣上积累了超过 77,000 名会员。

;

;根据该组织的数据在个人资料中，成员们信奉这样的座右铭：“再见，穿两双鞋的学生。”我要给自己颁发一份成就证书。”

;

;成员们分享了自己成为“模范生”的经历，并分析了这种心态如何阻碍职业发展、损害心理健康。

;

;在8月18日分享的帖子中，有人提出无条件服从权威可能是一种创伤。

;

;“我觉得可怕的是，我什至选择通过自动完成别人要求的任务来应对在他们发出命令之前！这样我就可以避免被指挥。这本质上相当于自残和自我驯化，”该人士说道。

;

;“所以收回自主权是关键！自己做决定，承担责任，重新获得对生活的掌控感。”他们补充道。

;

;北京师范大学心理学教授王芳告诉新京报：“从心理学角度来看，这种心态的根本代价就是失去真实的自我。

;

;“每个人本质上都是有价值的，但在长期的条件作用下，‘好学生’本能地开始相信，只有在满足一定条件时，自己才有价值。” ”，王说。

;

;“我认为，我们必须意识到这一点，以便找回自我并重新发现我们向他人屈服的主体性。这些人应该拥抱自我接纳、自我肯定、自我照顾和自爱。”她补充道。

;一位专注于拉丁美洲的经验丰富的中国外交官是一家半成品公司的新任负责人-负责促进与其他国家人文交流的官方机构。

;

;59岁的杨万明在中国人民对外友好协会主办的一次聚会上被介绍为中国人民对外友好协会（CPAFFC）会长。

;

;据该协会微信账号周二发布的消息称，他正在参加为期五天的活动的开幕式，该活动旨在促进中俄青年交流。

;< p>;杨接替林松添，林松添是一位资深外交官和非洲问题专家，自2020年起一直担任该协会会长。

;

;中国人民对外友好协会是一个半官方协会，其使命是扩大中国与其他国家之间的友好交流。国 - 也是北京更广泛的外交战略的一部分。

;

;在北京和华盛顿因问题陷入争执之际，它在通过民间交流改善与美国的关系方面发挥了作用。从贸易和技术到南海和台湾等许多问题。

;

;其中包括 2022 年 2 月组织的一次活动，中国外交部长王毅和美国前财政部长雅各布·卢出席了该活动。它重点关注50年前美国和中国在上海达成的联合公报，该公报标志着双边关系在二十年的对抗后开始解冻。

;

;杨洁篪的任命正值北京寻求更紧密的经济合作之际以及与巴西等拉丁美洲国家的安全关系，这些举动引起了华盛顿的怀疑和担忧。

;

;根据公布的数据，中国目前是拉丁美洲仅次于美国的第二大贸易伙伴六月，美国智库外交关系委员会提出了这一建议。

;

;该地区也是与台湾外交争端的一部分，北京声称台湾是其领土的一部分。洪都拉斯于 3 月将正式外交承认从台北转为北京，使得自治的台湾只剩下 13 个官方盟友，其中 7 个在拉丁美洲和加勒比地区。

;

;俄罗斯雇佣军首领叶夫根尼·普里戈任 (Yevgeny Prigozhin) 在乘坐私人飞机后被认为死亡。周三，一名乘客在莫斯科北部坠毁，无人生还。

;

;瓦格纳集团 62 岁的老板于 6 月 23 日至 24 日带头发动了针对俄罗斯高级军官的叛变，总统弗拉基米尔·普京表示，这可能会让俄罗斯陷入困境陷入内战。

;

;其他反对普京或其利益的人也已经死亡或在不明情况下濒临死亡。

;

;以下是有关这些神秘事件的一些详细信息：

;

; >;

;

;

;俄罗斯最著名的反对派领导人阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼 (Alexei Navalny) 在西伯利亚中毒，西方专家断定是军用神经毒剂诺维乔克 (Novichok)，他于 2020 年 8 月飞往德国接受治疗。

;

;俄罗斯否认有任何参与。

;

;纳瓦尔尼因在 2021 年自愿返回俄罗斯而赢得了全世界的钦佩。他一抵达就立即被捕。他目前因欺诈和其他他认为是虚假的指控而被判处总计 11.5 年徒刑。他的政治运动已被取缔并被宣布为“极端主义”。

;

;纳瓦尔尼最近在最高安全级别的流放地又被判处 19 年监禁。

;

;

;< p>;2018 年 3 月，曾向英国情报部门传递秘密的前俄罗斯双重间谍谢尔盖·斯克里帕尔 (Sergei Skripal) 和他的女儿尤利娅 (Yulia) 被发现昏迷不醒地躺在英国大教堂城索尔兹伯里一家购物中心外的长凳上。

;

;他们是被送往医院时情况危急，英国官员称他们是被诺维乔克（Novichok）中毒的，诺维乔克是苏联军方在20世纪70年代和80年代开发的一组神经毒剂。两人都幸存下来。

;

;俄罗斯否认与这起中毒事件有任何关系，并表示英国正在煽动反俄歇斯底里。

;

;

;

;前克格勃成员亚历山大·利特维年科 (Alexander Litvinenko)英国官员称，普京的特工和直言不讳的批评者于 2006 年在伦敦千禧酒店饮用掺有钋 210（一种稀有且强效放射性同位素）的绿茶后去世，享年 43 岁。

;

;普京可能批准了这一计划。英国的一项调查于 2016 年得出结论，克里姆林宫否认参与其中。

;

;英国一名高级法官领导的一项调查发现，前克格勃保镖安德烈·卢戈沃伊 (Andrei Lugovoy) 和另一名俄罗斯人德米特里·科夫通 (Dmitry Kovtun) 参与了这起杀戮事件。他说，这项行动可能是由俄罗斯联邦安全局 (FSB) 指挥的，俄罗斯联邦安全局是苏联时代克格勃的主要继承人。

;

;

;

;他说，他是在基辅郊外与乌克兰安全部门官员共进晚餐时中毒的。俄罗斯否认与此事有关。

;

;他的尸体被发现含有比正常情况多 1,000 倍的二恶英。他的脸和身体因中毒而毁容，之后接受了数十次手术。

;

;在乌克兰最高法院推翻了宣布亚努科维奇在街头获胜的结果后，他在重新进行的民意调查中赢得了总统职位被称为“橙色革命”的抗议活动。

;

;

;

;安娜·波利特科夫斯卡娅 (Anna Politkovskaya) 是一名报道侵犯人权行为的记者，2006 年 10 月 7 日返回莫斯科后，在她的公寓外被枪杀。

;

;48 岁的两个孩子的母亲波利特科夫斯卡娅 (Politkovskaya) 被谋杀，在西方引起了强烈抗议，并突显了人们对在俄罗斯工作的记者面临的危险的担忧。

;< h3>;;

;这位 44 岁的俄罗斯人于 2012 年 11 月外出慢跑后被发现死在伦敦郊外一处高级门禁庄园的豪宅附近。

;

;Alexander Perepilichny 寻求帮助2009年，在帮助瑞士调查俄罗斯洗钱计划后，逃往英国避难。他的突然死亡让人怀疑他可能是被谋杀的。

;英国警方排除了他杀的可能性，尽管怀疑他可能是被一种罕见的毒药谋杀的。预审听证会获悉，在他的胃中发现了来自钩吻植物的罕见致命毒物。

;

;程快手希望能够帮助用户在内容创作过程中生成文本、图像、音频和视频，帮助公司了解用户并提出更好的推荐。

;

; Thu, 24 Aug 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong’s low fertility rate shows urgency of creating a more family-friendly societyhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3231882/hong-kongs-low-fertility-rate-shows-urgency-creating-more-family-friendly-society?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.24 08:15;
;;

;香港人口增长正面临重大挑战，其中最大的挑战是该市的低生育率和老龄化社会。根据政府最新的人口预测，2021年总和生育率为每名妇女生育0.772个孩子，远低于2.1的更替水平，预计未来将进一步下降并维持在较低水平。

;<香港家庭计划协会的最新调查也显示，已婚妇女平均生育子女数已降至0.9个历史低位。无子女女性比例已达43.2%，较2017年增加一倍多，取代独生子女女性（27.4%）成为香港主流。

;

;尽管政府已采取各种措施鼓励生育，例如增加产假和陪产假的长度，这些措施似乎收效甚微。这是因为，与其他高收入亚洲社会一样，香港的年轻人在选择结婚和生育时必须权衡各种因素。

;

;其中包括高昂的住房和生活成本、女性比例的增加参与劳动力市场和更高的教育水平。这些因素使得年轻人更加难以承担生育和抚养孩子的费用，导致生育率较低。

;

;政府采取了更加乐观的态度，预计总和生育率将会反弹到 2026 年达到 0.9 以上，考虑到该市的生育率几十年来一直在下降，这不太可能。这意味着每年至少将有10,000名婴儿在香港出生。然而，我们正处于低生育率陷阱中，几乎没有机会减缓生育率的下降。

;

;此外，政府认为我们的人口将通过移民净增长来补充，从而抵消自然减少。 In an era of globalisation, immigration is an important factor in population growth. In Hong Kong, an international city, immigration plays a crucial role in population growth and is also an important force in promoting cultural assimilation and social development. Immigration can bring new talent and innovation, promoting economic development.

;

;However, it is also essential that these immigrants adapt and integrate well, or they may not stay long. This could even have a negative impact on attempts to build a better society and economy.

;

;The government's estimates for net gains from foreign talent and one-way permit holder arrivals are still fluid and uncertain. Even if the projections for births and migrants are accurate, Hong Kong would still face an acute ageing situation, with one in three people aged 65 or older by 2046. These trends will have far-reaching impacts on the city's economic and social development, necessitating a comprehensive response.

;

;Many of the negative effects will appear decades later but they can be felt even now with the closure of schools and kindergartens. The city's financial and economic development and sustainability face many difficulties. Piecemeal efforts will not be effective.

;

;The course of Hong Kong's population is not set in stone as it is based on assumptions that could be wrong. Nevertheless, it gives us a glimpse of our future. If we want to avoid this scenario, we must take action to ensure the current projections do not become reality.

;

;We need a comprehensive response. To achieve sustainable and healthier population development, more incentives are needed for young people to have children. These could include expanding maternity leave, building more nurseries and kindergartens, and offering child allowances and tax reductions. Such measures can help alleviate financial and social barriers that young families face when considering having children.

;

;Additionally, we must increase support for couples with children, such as by providing family allowances, reducing education expenses and offering more family medical services. These measures can help families raise their children, and will promote population growth and development.

;

;Finally, we must promote policies that attract more high-quality professionals, boosting economic development and population growth.

;

;More Hongkongers say no thanks to marriage, babies

;

;However, we must also ensure these migrants have a safe and comfortable environment in which to live and work. Efforts should also be made to slow the outflow of residents and make Hong Kong a place known for retaining talent.

;

;Ageing will become more acute and institutional care won't be enough. We need to promote community support and make it possible for more people to remain at home as they get older.

;

;For those without someone to care for them, we need to build more nursing homes, offer better medical services and implement elderly care policies to ensure they can live a healthy and comfortable life. Achieving healthy population development requires the support of society and policy changes.

;

;The city's fertility rate is expected to keep falling amid the increasing prevalence to delay marriage and women remaining single, as well as the stable trend of low birth rates.

;

;Good family planning education and awareness is critical. We need to remove barriers to fertility for those who want to have children and create a more family-friendly social environment. There is no silver bullet for raising the fertility rate – but a caring, warm and happy living environment will certainly help.

;Zimbabwe's president Wednesday extended voting by another day after long delays marred the start of balloting in key districts and sparked opposition accusations of “rigging” and “voter suppression”.

;

;As polling began to close in some voting stations, it was only starting in others, prompting opposition accusations of vote manipulation after a campaign marked by tension and a clampdown.

;

;“I do, by this proclamation in respect of the affected polling stations for the wards … fix the 24 of August 2023 as the last day of polling,” President Emmerson Mnangagwa announced in a presidential directive contained in a government notice.

;

;Less than a quarter of polling stations in Harare – an opposition stronghold – opened on time, according to electoral authorities, who blamed the problem on delays in the printing of ballot papers.

;

;“This is a clear case of voter suppression, a classic case of Stone Age, antiquated, analog rigging,” Nelson Chamisa, 45, the head of the leading opposition party, the Citizens Coalition for Change (CCC) told a press conference in the capital.

;

;Chamisa is the main challenger to Mnangagwa, 80, who came to power after a coup that deposed late ruler Robert Mugabe in 2017.

;

;Mnangagwa is seeking a second term in an election that came on a backdrop of widespread discontent at the southern African country's economic troubles.

;

;The poll is being watched across southern Africa as a test of support for the ZANU-PF party, whose 43-year rule has been battered by an economic slump and charges of authoritarianism.

;

;China, Zimbabwe seek stronger ties as Harare prepares for elections

;

;Chamisa blamed the governing ZANU-PF party, which has ruled the country since independence, for the delays, saying it was “desperate” to cling to power and risking plunging the country into a “crisis”.

;

;The electoral commission blamed the problem on delays in the printing of ballot papers “arising from numerous court challenges”.

;

;Polling in Harare's oldest suburb of Mbare started closing at around 7pm, while opening at another station in a suburb west of Harare.

;

;“This is a way to frustrate Harare voters. A way to manipulate the election results,” voter Tafadzwa Dhlodhlo said at a Warren Park polling station.

;

;Ballots at a school serving as a polling station in a poor neighbourhood arrived only after 2.30pm, whereas polling had been scheduled to start at 7am.

;

;“I am so disappointed,” said Linda Phiri, 53, a mother of three who had been waiting for eight hours. “I'm sleeping here. I want to cast that vote so that we are liberated,” said Phiri.

;

;Chamisa lashed out at the problems, saying it was a “classic of voter suppression” targeting CCC strongholds.

;

;“The fact they have targeted Harare … is an indication that they are scared of people in the urban areas.”

;

;Zimbabwe unveils 'majestic' US$200 million China-built parliament

;

;At least 6.6 million people were registered to vote, with more than a million living in Harare. Publication of the results is legally required within five days.

;

;To clinch re-election, Mnangagwa must win an absolute majority or face a run-off.

;

;Casting his ballot in his hometown of Kwekwe in central Zimbabwe, a confident Mnangagwa – nicknamed the “Crocodile” for his determination – said: “If I think I'm not going to take it, then I will be foolish.”

;

;The opposition has been hoping to ride a wave of discontent over corruption, high inflation, unemployment and entrenched poverty.

; Thu, 24 Aug 2023 07:20:01 +0800 Taiwan arms boost: US approves US$500 million in F-16 sensor systems for island’s defencehttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3232095/taiwan-arms-boost-us-approves-us500-million-f-16-sensor-systems-islands-defence?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;The US government has approved a half-billion-dollar sale of advanced sensor systems for F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan to boost the self-governing island's ability to defend against “threats”, according to a State Department statement on Wednesday.

;

;The deal would include the F-16 infrared search-and-track system and related equipment at an estimated cost of US$500 million, according to the statement. Congress was officially notified of the sale on Wednesday, it added.

;

;Built by US aerospace company Lockheed Martin, the equipment would improve Taiwan's defence of its airspace and deepen interoperability with the US through its F-16 programme, the statement said.

;

;The US in 2019 approved a US$8 billion sale of 66 F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan, a deal taking the island's F-16 fleet to more than 200 jets by 2026, the largest in Asia.

;

;In March, the Biden administration approved the sale of an estimated US$619 million in arms to Taiwan, including hundreds of missiles for F-16 fighter jets.

;

;The advanced sensor system functionality on offer can detect and track threats at long ranges and is unique in that it does not emit radiation, thus enhancing the lethality and survivability of aircrews.

;

;Yet the proposed deal would not alter the region's basic military balance, according to the statement.

;

;Reports earlier this year stated that Chinese President Xi Jinping had ordered the country's military be ready by 2027 to invade Taiwan, but at present he may be harbouring doubts about its ability to do so, according to US intelligence.

;

;On Monday, Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen said the island's defence spending in 2024 would reach a record US$19 billion and that it would seek “more international support”.

;

;US Air Force holds China war drill rehearsing evacuation of thousands

;

;Taiwan aimed to complete its upgrade of 141 F-16A/B fighter jets by the end of this year, Tsai also said on Monday.

;

;The latest developments, transpiring as tensions have stayed high in the Taiwan Strait for months, could further strain ties between Beijing and Washington.

;

;Over the weekend, the People's Liberation Army launched large-scale, live-fire war games around Taiwan.

;

;The action sent a clear signal of Beijing's displeasure over the recent US travel itinerary taken by William Lai Ching-te, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate for the island's presidential election next year.

;

;To Beijing, Taiwan is a breakaway province to be reunited with the mainland, by force if necessary. It opposes any official interaction between Taipei and Washington as well as American arms sales to the island.

;

;PLA sorties force Taiwan's military fuel budget up 55 per cent to US$344 million

;

;But under the Biden administration, such transactions have taken place more frequently and quickly.

;

;The White House last month announced a US$345 million weapons package for Taiwan, marking the first time the US used presidential drawdown authority for an arms sale to the island and enabling Washington to send Taipei weapons from its own stockpiles.

;

;The State Department statement on Wednesday said the deal arose from a request by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington – Taiwan's de facto embassy in the US.

;

;It said the sale included aircraft and munitions support, training equipment, personnel training and related logistical and programme support.

;

;The Chinese embassy in Washington did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

;

;In response to previous US weapons sales to Taiwan, Beijing urged Washington to stop selling arms to the island, saying they “could lead to tensions” and “pose risks to peace” in the Taiwan Strait.

;

;Additional reporting by Mark Magnier in New York

;Beijing sees the deepening of Japanese-South Korean ties as part of the US strategy to contain its rise through a vast network of alliances and partnerships. ;

;The Camp David summit between US President Joe Biden, South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida was the result of renewed efforts by Tokyo and Seoul to try to set aside their historical disputes in the face of shared security concerns over China's geopolitical assertiveness and North Korea's growing nuclear and missile capabilities.

;Pushed by the US, Japan and South Korea probably have a window of four years to cement their rapprochement. The time frame coincides with the remaining period in office for Yoon, who is risking his political capital at home to mend ties with Tokyo after relations deteriorated under his predecessor Moon Jae-in.

;

;Japan and South Korea have long had tense interactions because of the Japanese colonial occupation of the Korean peninsula. Tensions skyrocketed after Moon rejected a 2015 arrangement on the “comfort women” issue.

;

;During reciprocal visits in March and May, Yoon and Kishida moved to break the ice. They achieved a solution for compensation to victims of Japan's wartime forced labour before and during World War II.

;

;The Japanese government also lifted export controls on critical materials needed to manufacture semiconductors it had levelled against South Korea. In turn, Seoul withdrew its action brought against Tokyo at the World Trade Organization over what it considered illegal restrictions.

;

;Building on their two previous meetings, Kishida and Yoon met together with Biden on the sidelines of the Group of 7 summit in Hiroshima in May. Among other results, the three leaders agreed to advance cooperation in sharing North Korea's missile data in real time, a commitment confirmed during the talks at Camp David.

;

;South Korea and Japan are united by the common imperative of preventing a revisionist China from becoming a regional hegemon in East Asia, and it is reasonable for them to remain under the security umbrella of an external balancer such as the US.

;

;Japan views China's rise as a source of instability in East Asia and is prepared to take steps to curb it, even if it involves an economic cost. Tokyo has, for example, joined a US-sponsored ban on the sales of chip equipment to Chinese tech companies, a move that is impacting some Japanese exporters and has angered Beijing.

;

;The Kishida administration plans to raise military spending to 2 per cent of GDP by 2027 to deal with challenges from China, North Korea and Russia. In particular, Tokyo wants to be able to launch counter-attacks on enemy bases in an emergency using “stand-off missiles” provided by the US.

;

;Its geographical proximity to China, deep economic connections and Beijing's influence over the North Korean leadership have long prompted Seoul to adopt a more nuanced approach to Chinese ascendance. Factors such as Beijing's increasing military pressure on Taiwan – which Yoon has opposed, calling it an attempt to change the status quo in the region – and North Korea's repeated missile advances are changing South Korea's perspective.

;

;South Korea understands the need for security cooperation with Tokyo to improve operational readiness against China's military manoeuvres and North Korea's projectiles. Reducing dependence on China's economy by increasing bilateral trade and investment, and ensuring safe supply chains, is another common point in Japan and South Korea's security equation.

;

;Both have an interest in reducing the impact of possible economic coercion by China – Beijing has a track record of using this tool to advance its geopolitical agenda – and hedging against China's slowing economy. This is why Tokyo and Seoul are working to create strategic synergy on semiconductors.

;

;Samsung reportedly intends to build a microchip development facility in Yokohama, where the South Korean tech giant already has a research unit. Japan and South Korea have also reached a consensus on expanding collaboration in other critical fields, such as liquefied natural gas, space and biotechnology.

;

;The two nations will also have to protect their reinvigorated security and economic cooperation from the risk of a possible U-turn by future left-leaning South Korean administrations or by Japanese governments pressed by conservative nationalist groups – particularly within Kishida's Liberal Democratic Party – that oppose concessions on historical issues.

;

;China concerned US, South Korea, Japan could form new military alliance

;

;Disagreements over Japan's colonial history will persist but will have less of an impact as a younger generation of leaders and citizens emerges and the perception of a China threat grows among Japanese and South Koreans.

;

;Cooperation with the US and Japan is South Korea's geopolitical insurance against the risks associated with a more dominant China. Any incumbent government in Seoul knows that US military deterrence in East Asia can only reach its full strength with the combined help of Tokyo and Seoul.

;

;After all, despite Moon's cautious approach to China, South Korea's military budget has steadily risen during his tenure. The focus on a naval build-up suggests improving the country's defences has more to do with possible disputes with China than a crisis with North Korea.

;US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo's visit to China will set the stage for top-level leadership meetings and serve as a “reality check” on American business in China's struggling economy, according to Chinese analysts.

;

;Raimondo's trip, from Sunday to Wednesday, would make her the latest US official dispatched to China since June, in a sign that stalled high-level visits between the world's largest economies are resuming amid growing tensions stemming from geopolitical wrangling.

;

;Geopolitical experts also see her visit as another step toward a meeting between presidents Xi Jinping and Joe Biden in San Francisco on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) Leaders' Meeting in November.

;

;Yet, Raimondo's China itinerary appears different from those of previous US officials, as it includes a stop in Shanghai along with Beijing, where she is expected to meet high-ranking officials.

;

;From Raimondo to deflation: 4 things to look for in China's economy in August

;

;A source with knowledge of Raimondo's trip told the Post that she will meet with the Shanghai party secretary and the American Chamber of Commerce in Shanghai, along with visits to New York University Shanghai and, tentatively, Shanghai Disneyland.

;

;Shanghai is China's commercial capital for foreign investment and where more than 1,000 American companies are registered with AmCham Shanghai.

;

;“[It is] a fairly light schedule from a policy standpoint, which suggests her visit is to reinforce stable US-China communications ahead of the upcoming Apec meeting,” the source said on condition of anonymity.

;

;Pang Zhongying, a chair professor in international political economy at Sichuan University in Chengdu, said Raimondo's trip comes at a time when American business could be shifting away from China due to political and economic concerns.

;

;“Her stop in Shanghai means she will engage with major American business representatives in China, to understand how they are operating in the current economy, and to make a fresh assessment of China's business environment,” Pang said.

;

;China's economy is recovering slower than expected. The nation's gross domestic product (GDP) grew just 0.8 per cent in the second quarter compared with the first quarter – down from 2.2 per cent in the first three months of 2023. Overall foreign direct investment to China also dropped by 9.8 per cent, year on year, in the first seven months of 2023, according to the Ministry of Commerce.

;

;And for the first time in the 25-year history of AmCham China's Business Climate Survey, firms said earlier this year that China was no longer a “top-three investment priority”.

;

;While Raimondo has repeated calls by Biden and other Western leaders – that they are looking to “de-risk” instead of “decouple” from China in the supply chain – Pang said American business could still be leaving China for economic reasons.

;

;“In a way, her trip could be a reality check for the US – to prepare as more American business could be withdrawing from the Chinese market,” Pang said.

;

;In the lead-up to Raimondo's visit, US commerce officials on Monday announced the removal of 27 Chinese entities from its unverified list, a de facto trade restriction that subjects identified companies to more stringent scrutiny than normal before they are allowed to do business with US suppliers.

;

;Just weeks ago, Biden signed an executive order to add a screening mechanism in the US Treasury, for American investment in private equity and venture capital in China's semiconductors, artificial intelligence and quantum computing, citing “national security” concerns.

;

;“By now, it is clear that the Biden administration's diplomatic gestures and economic coercive policies go hand in hand,” said Ren Xiao, a professor and director of the Centre for the Study of Chinese Foreign Policy at Fudan University.

;

;Beijing similarly cited national-security grounds earlier this year when cracking down on foreign consultancies, prompting warnings that China was scaring away investors.

;

;Handshakes and 'candid' talks, but what is the outlook for US-China relations?

;

;Raimondo's scheduled meetings represent the fourth major Beijing sit-down between the two sides this summer, following trips by Secretary of State Antony Blinken, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and climate envoy John Kerry. Veteran US diplomat Henry Kissinger was also given a red-carpet welcome in his return to Beijing last month.

;

;“Raimondo's visit would be a continuation of the gesture that both sides are willing to continue communicating, which is better than nothing,” Ren said.

;

;During a meeting with Raimondo in the US on Tuesday, China's ambassador to the US, Xie Feng, touched on areas of concern and called for Washington to take “substantial action” toward resolving trade and economic problems and to stabilise relations.

;

;Premier Li Qiang also took an opportunity this week to express his concerns over bilateral relations as he received a US delegation.

;

;“At present, China-US relations and economic and trade cooperation are facing some difficulties, which require both sides to show sincerity … and make joint efforts,” Li told the US-China Business Council delegation led by its chair, Marc Casper, on Monday, according to the state news agency Xinhua.

;

;Moving forward, Ren and Pang both noted that the big question is when Xi and Biden may meet, and “whether Xi would actually pay a state visit to the US”, on top of the Apec meeting.

;

;“I don't think they have decided on that, yet,” Ren said.
